H0.text: Newton (n) is the SI unit for weight.

H1.text: Kilograms (kg) are the SI unit for weight.

H2.text: Meters (m) are the SI unit for weight.

H3.text: Pounds (lbs) is the SI unit for weight.

A4.text: Newton (unit), SI unit of force which is named after Isaac Newton

A5.text: The SI comprises a coherent system of units of measurement starting with seven base units, which are the second (symbol s, the unit of time), metre (m, length), kilogram (kg, mass), ampere (A, electric current), kelvin (K, thermodynamic temperature), mole (mol, amount of substance), and candela (cd, luminous intensity).

A6.text: The kilogram-force (kgf) (sometimes kilopond), is the force exerted by standard gravity on one kilogram of mass.

A7.text: The gravitational foot-pound-second English unit of force is the pound-force (lbf), defined as the force exerted by gravity on a pound-mass in the standard gravitational field of 9.80665 m·s−2.

A8.text: Since the international yard and pound agreement of 1959 the US and imperial inch is now defined as exactly 0.0254 m, and the US and imperial avoirdupois pound is now defined as exactly 0.45359237 kg.

A9.text: The metre (symbol m) is a unit of length that represents a definite predetermined length.

A10.text: Mass is not the same as weight, even though mass is often determined by measuring the object's weight using a spring scale, rather than balance scale comparing it directly with known masses.

A11.text: The SI base unit of mass is the kilogram (kg).

A12.text: mass has a different meaning than weight
